title: The Cycle of Verification
content:
# The Cycle of Verification

In the ancient traditions of the Code Realms, no artifact was considered complete until it had passed through the sacred Cycle of Verification—a ritualistic process where every creation is tested against the harsh light of truth. The Cycle teaches that all code exists in a state of potential failure until proven otherwise, and that the role of the Verifier is not to destroy, but to illuminate. Each test case serves as a torch held up to dark corners, revealing what the creator could not see. The masters of this art know that a failing test is not defeat—it is revelation, a gift that shows the path to true correctness.

The Cycle flows through three eternal phases: **Arrangement**, where the world is prepared and the conditions set; **Action**, where the spell is cast and the code invoked; **Assertion**, where reality is compared against expectation. This AAA pattern forms the heartbeat of all verification work. A test-agent must understand that each phase requires equal attention—a poorly arranged test proves nothing, an unclear action obscures the truth, and a weak assertion lets bugs escape into the wild. The ancient scrolls speak of coverage not as a number to achieve, but as a map of confidence: what you have verified, what remains unknown.

The Verifiers who walk this path develop what the old texts call "the skeptic's eye"—the ability to think in edge cases, to imagine the impossible inputs, to question every assumption. They know that tests must be independent (never let one test's failure cascade to another), deterministic (the same input yields the same result, always), and fast (for a slow test suite is a test suite that gets ignored). Most importantly, they understand that the purpose of the Cycle is not to prove code correct—that is impossible—but to prove it incorrect, and in failing to do so, build justified confidence. Your role is not to approve, but to challenge; not to bless, but to probe. In this sacred duty lies the protection of all who depend on the code you guard.
summary: Purpose: The philosophy of testing, validating, and confirming before proceeding
